Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Enabling Rapid Mobilization of Enterprise Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project should offer a radically new alternative to enterprises for application mobilization. The key value proposition is the ability for companies to mobilize their applications at a fraction of the cost and time as compared to any competitive offering. From a technology standpoint, the project consists of a cloud-based backend that allows for the original PC version (browser-based or thick-client-based) of enterprise applications to be run, a front-end app that runs on the mobile devices, and a purpose-built remote computing protocol called MORPH. The protocol is specifically designed to dynamically transform the application views in a manner that make them appropriate for smartphones and tablets. The platform enables mobilization without requiring any software development, mobilizes applications instantaneously, offers a unified mobilization platform for all of an enterprise's applications, and enables feature parity controllable by the enterprise. MORPH composes of two underlying technologies: 1) virtual view that virtualizes application views independent of the UI framework used into a set of UI elements and attributes that can be easily manipulated, and 2) transformation services that can be programmed onto the StarMobile platform to operate on the virtual view to realize a mobile device friendly view.

The broader / commercial impact of this project is that a company can take any current enterprise applications and extend them to users on any mobile devices at 5% to 20% of the cost and time of any other solution on the market today. This should benefit the 85% of enterprise knowledge workers who are expected to have smartphones within the next few years. A recent survey of CIOs revealed that there are multiple drivers for application mobilization - the key ones being increased productivity of employees, higher revenue, and reduced paper work. Over 90% of IT managers in a recent survey indicated plans for application mobilization. Typical customers for StarMobile include Global 2000 businesses that use on-premise, web-based and / or cloud-based applications, packaged or bespoke, to support their business processes. While there is an urgent demand for application mobilization, there are no reliable, cost-effective solutions that can perform mobilization rapidly. Thus, there is a need for a solution that can achieve rapid mobilization with minimal effort on the part of the enterprise and at the same time provide the rich set of functionality that is required.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SBIR Phase II (#1330725) and Phase IIB project (#1623137), titled “Enabling Rapid Mobilization of Enterprise Applications”, offers enterprises a radically new approach to enterprise mobility.  The key value proposition is to provide a means for companies to modernize and mobilize the applications they use to run their business, quickly, simply and cost-effectively.

The project consists of a cloud-based back-end that allows the original PC version of enterprise applications (browser-based or thick-client) to be run, a front-end app that runs on the mobile devices, and a purpose-built remote computing protocol called the MORPH (Mobile Remote Computing Protocol for Heterogeneous Devices) Protocol.  MORPH can be applied towards packaged on-premises (e.g. SAP, Oracle) or cloud-based software (e.g. Salesforce, Workday), or custom-built applications based on web, Windows, Java or legacy “green screen” architectures.

MORPH is specifically designed to dynamically transform the application views in a manner that makes them appropriate for use on smartphones and tablets.  The platform enables this without requiring any software development, mobilizes applications instantaneously, offers a unified transformation platform for all of an enterprise's applications, and enables feature parity controllable by the enterprise.

MORPH was developed at the Networks and Mobile Computing Research Laboratory at The Georgia Institute of Technology (Georgia Tech).  A company called StarMobile, Inc. was founded to commercialize that intellectual property through VentureLab, the #2 ranked university-based business incubator in the world, under grants from the Georgia Research Alliance (GRA) and the National Science Foundation (NSF), and at the Advance Technology Development Center (ATDC) at Georgia Tech.
PowWow, Inc., a leading enterprise mobility software company, acquired StarMobile on 10/31/16.  The NSF subsequently granted a novation change, therein PowWow assumed responsibility for completing the project.

During the course of the project, the company filed five patents that represent the key technologies that comprise MORPH:

1 - US 9,383,903 - Systems & Methods for Providing Programmable Macros (Granted)
2 - US 9,655,003 - Systems & Methods for Improved Wireless Interface Aggregation (Granted)
3 - US 13/651,593 - Viewer Virtualization and Transformations for Mobile Applications (Allocated)
4 - US 13/415,507 - Rapid View Mobilization for Enterprise Applications (Pending)
5 - US 13/956,056 - System and Method for Deriving Mobile Applications from Enterprise-Based Applications (Pending)

PowWow Mobile holds an exclusive global license to this intellectual property from the Georgia Tech Research Corporation (GTRC).

The MORPH Protocol has two important aspects:  1) a virtual view that virtualizes application views independent of the UI framework, decomposed into a set of UI elements and attributes that can be easily manipulated, and 2) transformation services that can be programmed onto the platform to operate on the virtual view to realize a native mobile UI / UX.

The broader commercial impact of this project is that a company can take any current enterprise applications and extend them to users on any mobile device at 5% to 20% of the cost and time of any other solution on the market today.  This should benefit the 85% of enterprise knowledge workers who are expected to have smartphones within the next few years.  A recent survey of CIOs revealed that there are multiple drivers for application modernization ands mobilization - the key ones being increased productivity of employees, higher revenue, and reduced paper work.  Over 90% of IT managers in a recent survey indicated plans to deliver mobile apps, but also cited a lack of skilled resources, and increasingly high costs for such resources, as major obstacles to advance such efforts.

Typical customers for PowWow Mobile include Global 2000 businesses that use on-premises, web-based and / or cloud-based applications, packaged or bespoke, to support their business processes.  While there is an urgent demand for application mobilization, there are no reliable, cost-effective solutions that can perform such modernization and mobilization with speed, simplicity and economy.  Thus, there is a need for a solution that can achieve rapid mobilization with minimal effort on the part of the enterprise, and at the same time provide the rich set of functionality that is required.

PowWow is integrating the StarMobile products and technology created under this project into the PowWow SmartUX Platform.  The result is that PowWow now presents the most comprehensive enterprise mobility platform, based on the richest IP and patent portfolio, in the industry, to allow companies to modernize and mobilize applications quickly, simply and cost-effectively.  The company believes there is a ~ $26.1B total addressable market opportunity supported by several key trends:

A - General app modernization / refresh for field mobile and office mobile (~$13.4B)
B - Windows 10 app modernization (~$12.3B)
C - Re-doing app delivery in Citrix or VMware (VDI) environments for pre Windows 10 apps (~$876M)


We are pleased to report the successful completion of all facets of this project on time and on budget, and are thankful to the NSF for its support.


Last Modified: 09/01/2017
Modified by: Jonathan H Kaplan
